subject: polity
title: Legislative Procedures - Bills & Joint Sitting
description: Comprehensive guide to Ordinary Bills, Money Bills, Financial Bills, and Joint Sitting procedures in Indian Parliament

rows.definition:
• Bills on any matter EXCEPT financial matters (Art 107)
• Can be Constitutional Amendment Bill, Criminal Law Bill, etc.
• Needs passage by **both Houses** with **simple majority**
rows.introduction:
• Can be introduced in **either House**
• By Minister (Govt Bill) or Private Member (Fri)
• Requires 7 days notice
rows.passageProcedure:
**Stages:**
1. First Reading (Introduction)
2. Second Reading (General discussion + Clause-by-clause + Amendments)
3. Third Reading (Final vote)
4. Sent to other House (same 3 stages)
5. Presidential Assent
rows.rsPowers:
• **Equal powers** to LS
• Can reject, amend, delay
• If deadlock → Joint Sitting (Art 108)
• RS can delay max **6 months** (combined both rejections)
rows.presidentsAssent:
• President can give assent
• Or withhold (Pocket Veto)
• Or return for reconsideration (Suspensive Veto)
• If Parliament passes again, President MUST assent

rows.definition:
• Deals **ONLY** with matters in **Art 110(1)** (a) to (g):
(a) Taxes
(b) Borrowing of money
(c) Consolidated/Contingency Fund
(d) Appropriation of funds
(e) Declaring expenditure charged
(f) Receipt of money
(g) Matters incidental to above
• **Speaker certifies** if bill is Money Bill (Art 110(3)) - Final & binding
rows.introduction:
• Can be introduced **ONLY in Lok Sabha**
• By a Minister only (No Private Member's Money Bill)
• Requires **President's recommendation** (Art 117)
rows.passageProcedure:
**Stages:**
1-3. Three readings in LS (same as Ordinary Bill)
4. Sent to RS
5. RS has **14 days** to recommend (not binding)
6. LS accepts/rejects RS recommendations
7. Presidential Assent (cannot return)
rows.rsPowers:
• **Very limited powers**
• Can only recommend amendments (**not binding**)
• **14 days** to return
• If 14 days lapse, deemed passed by both
• **Cannot reject or amend**
rows.presidentsAssent:
• President **cannot return** Money Bill
• Must give assent (Art 111)
• **No Pocket Veto** for Money Bills
• **No Suspensive Veto**

rows.definition:
• Contains provisions of **Art 110** (Money Bill) + **Other matters**
• Example: Bill imposing tax + creating regulatory body
• Mixed nature
rows.introduction:
• Can be introduced **ONLY in Lok Sabha**
• By Minister only
• Requires **President's recommendation** (Art 117(1))
rows.passageProcedure:
**Stages:**
1-3. Three readings in LS
4. Sent to RS
5. RS can amend **non-financial** provisions
6. RS can delay, but LS can override
7. If deadlock → **Joint Sitting possible**
rows.rsPowers:
• Can amend **non-Money Bill provisions**
• **Cannot amend Money Bill provisions**
• Can delay but not reject
• Stronger than Money Bill, weaker than Ordinary Bill
rows.presidentsAssent:
• President can return (Suspensive Veto)
• Can exercise Pocket Veto
• Similar to Ordinary Bill

rows.definition:
• Involves expenditure from **Consolidated Fund** but doesn't fall under **Art 110**
• Example: Bill increasing salary of judges
• NOT a Money Bill
rows.introduction:
• Can be introduced in **either House**
• Requires **President's recommendation** for consideration (not introduction)
• Can be introduced by Private Member (but can't be considered without President's nod)
rows.passageProcedure:
**Stages:**
1-5. Same as Ordinary Bill (all three readings in both Houses)
6. If deadlock → **Joint Sitting possible**
7. Presidential Assent
rows.rsPowers:
• **Equal powers** to LS (like Ordinary Bill)
• Can amend, reject, delay
• If deadlock → Joint Sitting
• Max 6 months delay
rows.presidentsAssent:
• President can return (Suspensive Veto)
• Can exercise Pocket Veto
• Same as Ordinary Bill

rows.definition:
• Called by **President** to resolve **deadlock** between LS & RS on Ordinary/Financial Bills (NOT Money Bills)
• Deadlock = Bill rejected by one House after passage by other; OR Amendments not agreed; OR 6 months lapsed
rows.introduction:
• **Presided by LS Speaker**
• If Speaker absent, Deputy Speaker
• If both absent, Deputy Chairman of RS
rows.passageProcedure:
**Quorum**: 1/10th of total members (LS+RS) = 79 members (543+245)/10
**Voting**: Simple majority of members present
**LS dominance**: LS has 543 vs RS 245 → LS will prevail
rows.rsPowers:
• **Only 3 Joint Sittings** in history:
1. Dowry Prohibition Bill (1960)
2. Banking Service Commission (Repeal) Bill (1978)
3. POTA (2002)
rows.presidentsAssent:
• After Joint Sitting, bill deemed passed by both Houses
• President gives assent
• No return/Pocket Veto for Joint Sitting bills (by convention)

notes: **Money Bill Supremacy**: Speaker's certificate (Art 110(3)) is final - Courts cannot question it (only examine if procedural requirements met)
**LS Dominance**: LS more powerful in financial matters (Money Bills, Budget, Grants); RS can only delay Ordinary Bills by 6 months max
**Joint Sitting Rarity**: Only 3 Joint Sittings since 1950 - Shows spirit of cooperation between Houses

**President's Veto Types**: (1) **Absolute** - Withholds assent, bill ends; (2) **Suspensive** - Returns for reconsideration (Parliament can override); (3) **Pocket** - Takes no action (bill pending indefinitely)
**Art 110 vs 117**: Art 110 = Money Bills only; Art 117(1) = Financial Bill Type I (Money + Other); Art 117(3) = Financial Bill Type II (Expenditure from Consolidated Fund)
**President's Recommendation**: Required for introduction of Money Bills & Financial Bill Type I; Required for consideration (not introduction) of Financial Bill Type II
**Important Case**: **Raja Ram Pal (2007)** - Speaker's decision to expel members upheld; Art 122(1) protects parliamentary proceedings from judicial review unless constitutional violation
examTips: **Money Bill vs Ordinary Bill**: Money Bill only Art 110 matters, only LS, 14 days RS, no return; Ordinary Bill any matter except financial, both Houses, 6 months delay, can be returned
**Speaker's Certificate**: Art 110(3) - Final on whether bill is Money Bill; Courts can't question (except procedural challenge)
**Joint Sitting**: Art 108 - Only for Ordinary/Financial Bills, NOT Money Bills; LS Speaker presides; LS dominates (543 vs 245); Only 3 times used
**President's Recommendation**: Art 117 - Money Bills & Fin Bill Type I need for introduction; Fin Bill Type II needs for consideration
**6 months delay**: RS can delay Ordinary Bill max 6 months (1st rejection = 6 months; 2nd rejection = further time till Joint Sitting)
**14 days for Money Bill**: RS must return within 14 days; If not, deemed passed; RS recommendations not binding on LS
**Financial Bills**: Type I (Money + Other, only LS, Joint Sitting possible); Type II (Expenditure CF, either House, like Ordinary Bill)
